description.narrative:
For the Colombian economy to grow sustainably and to break the inequality of today’s system, to meet the challenges of tomorrow’s labour market and overcome decades of conflict that has deeply fragmented the society, changes at the labour market are necessary. Such developments are strongly dependent on a shift in culture and perception not just in the dialogue between the employers and the trade unions, but within these groups and bodies themselves. The project “Private Sector contribution to Social Dialogue in Colombia", NIR (International Council of Swedish Industry) intends to strengthen the dialogue through building trust and providing access to tools among actors at different levels at the labour market.
This two and half year project further intends to support Colombia’s OECD implementation process by addressing needs identified in the recent OECD assessments of the labour market. The project focuses on three components; to create a labour market dialogue initiative, to develop the mediation mechanism for the labour market at firm level as well as to design local social dialogue workplace programs - all activities with a shared long-term outcome; to achieve an improved capacity for a sustainable social dialogue. The project starts with an initial phase of six months, to ensure that the specific plans are developed and modified in close cooperation with local stakeholders.

För att den colombianska ekonomin ska växa hållbart och bryta ojämlikheterna i dagens system, möta utmaningarna på morgondagens arbetsmarknad samt övervinna årtionden av konflikter som har splittrat samhället, är förändringar på arbetsmarknaden nödvändiga. Sådan utveckling är starkt beroende av en förändring av kultur och uppfattningar, inte bara i dialogen mellan arbetsgivare och fackföreningar, utan inom dessa grupper och organisationer själva. Under projektet “Private Sector contribution to Social Dialogue in Colombia", avser NIR att stärka denna dialogen genom att bygga förtroende och ge tillgång till verktyg bland aktörer på olika nivåer på arbetsmarknaden.
Detta två och ett halvårsprojekt avser vidare att stödja Colombias genomförandeprocessen av Colombias nyligen godkända OECD medlemskap genom att addressera de behov som identifierats i de senaste OECD-bedömningarna beträffande Colombias arbetsmarknad.
Projektet fokuserar på tre komponenter; att skapa ett arbetsmarknadsdialoginitiativ, att utveckla medlingsmekanismen på arbetsmarknaden samt att utforma ett arbetsplatsprogram för sociala dialog på arbetsmarknadens - alla aktiviteter delar ett långsiktigt mål, att uppnå en bättre kapacitet för en hållbar social dialog. Projektet börjar med en första fas på sex månader för att säkerställa att de specifika aktiviteterna utvecklas i nära samarbete med lokala intressenter.

The aim of the programme Private Sector contribution to Social Dialogue in Colombia is to provide improved conditions for a Sustainable Social Dialogue. The program targets social dialogue on three levels; social dialogue among the labour market parties at 1) central, regional and sectorial level 2) the company and firm level and 3) the workplace level. The combination of these tracks is intended to be mutually reinforcing, and to provide several avenues to reach results. Thus, strengthen the dialogue through building trust and providing access to tools among actors at different levels at the labour market. Hence, the project focuses on three components; to create a labour market dialogue initiative, to develop the mediation mechanism for the labour market at firm level as well as to design local social dialogue workplace programs - all activities with a shared long-term outcome; to achieve an improved capacity for a sustainable social dialogue. This two and half year project further intends to support Colombia’s OECD accession process by addressing needs identified in the recent OECD assessments of the labour market.

description.narrative:
As stated in the last conclusion on performance, dated the 6th of June, 2022, regarding the first output, which aims at putting in place an operational structure for future dialogue between the government, the three main national Trade Unions and employers (represented by ANDI) as part of the OECD agenda, the Embassy's assessment is that progress was very limited in 2021. The polarized context caused by the massive popular opposition to the governmental proposed tax reform, impeded any dialogue during the first half of the year. The three main trade unions joined the National Strike Committee and protests continued during April and May 2021 leading to violent clashes with the National police. NIR visited Bogota in October 2021 and met with the three trade unions, ANDI and the Ministry of Labour. All three sides confirmed the difficulties of trying to re-establish a dialogue between all parties. Therefore, they all agreed to focus on the mediation component with Andi concentrating on the sectoral basis and the Ministry on alternative labour market dialogue initiatives. Given all of this and the fact that NIR had only used 31% of the approved budget for this component during 2021, on November the 9th,2021, NIR requested an extension but without the need for any additional funds. A second amendment to the agreement was signed through an exchange of e-mails on November the 30th,2021, thereby extending the activity period until August 2022.
Despite their obvious frustration with Andi and the Government, the Trade Unions participated in the Global Deal event held in Cartagena on November the 25th and 26th, 2021. Representatives from NIR, some Swedish companies (Electrolux, SKF, Securitas and Scania), Swedish Trade Union (LO) also participated together with the Swedish Ambassador. The General Director for Trade from the Swedish Ministry for Foreign Affairs opened the event together with the OECD Secretary General and the ILO Director General. The Swedish Ambassador closed the event by emphasizing the importance of fostering democratic institutions, protecting human rights defenders, promoting business formalization and promoting the participation of employees in decisions taken by companies as important steps for promoting social dialogue. NIR contributed to this event by attracting Swedish company participation and by talking about the first years experience of the Swedish workplace program.
Regarding the second output, which aims at reactivating a resource pool of mediators, the Embassy's assessment is that NIR made progress in 2021. The mediation component is recognized by all stakeholders as a possible way forward to help improve relations between employers and employees and is seen as a good alternative to the current practice of addressing labour conflicts through lengthy judicial processes. The alliance with Universidad Javeriana has opened new opportunities as it is an actor outside the social dialogue but one that is recognized by all parties (Ministry of Labour, employers and employees). Despite some delays due to the Covid 19 restrictions, three seminars on Alternative Conflict Resolution Mechanisms (MASC is its acronym in Spanish), research and a course on mediation, were the main activities undertaken in 2021. The results of the seminars and research were presented by Javeriana in the Global Deal event in Cartagena on November the 26th, 2021. The Embassy's assessment is that this second component made significant progress thanks to the alliance with Javeriana University and that it could be consolidated during 2022.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
